security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill that provides testing patterns and guidelines. It contains no executable code, network calls, or file operations. The skill is purely instructional with test organization patterns, naming conventions, and best practices.

content.value_statement: Testing code without proper patterns leads to flaky tests and maintenance nightmares. This skill provides battle-tested patterns for unit, integration, and E2E tests with proper fixtures and naming conventions.
actual_capabilities: Provides testing patterns for unit, integration, and E2E tests
Defines naming conventions for test files and functions
Sets coverage requirements by component type
Provides red flags to avoid when writing tests

use_cases.title: Organize test suite structure
use_cases.description: Structure tests properly with unit, integration, and E2E separation following industry best practices

use_cases.title: Create reliable test fixtures
use_cases.description: Build maintainable fixtures and mocks that ensure test isolation and reproducibility

use_cases.title: Integrate testing in CI/CD
use_cases.description: Set up automated testing pipelines with appropriate test execution strategies

prompt_templates.title: Basic test structure
prompt_templates.scenario: Create unit test for a function
prompt_templates.prompt: Using the testing patterns skill, create a unit test for a Python function that calculates order totals. Include proper setup, test isolation, and cleanup.

prompt_templates.title: Integration test setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Following the integration testing patterns, write tests for a REST API endpoint that handles user registration. Include database fixtures and mock external services.

prompt_templates.title: E2E test workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an E2E test using the patterns provided that tests a complete user login and purchase flow. Include proper timeouts and browser automation.

prompt_templates.title: Custom fixtures
prompt_templates.prompt: Based on the fixture patterns, create reusable test fixtures for an e-commerce application including users, products, and orders with proper relationships.

output_examples.input: Create unit test patterns for a payment processing module
output: Mock external services: payment gateway API
Test isolation: Each test creates fresh payment object
Coverage target: 90% for core payment logic

best_practices: Always use proper test isolation to prevent flaky tests
Follow the naming conventions consistently across the project
Use fixtures instead of hardcoding test data
anti_patterns: Writing tests without proper cleanup that leave state behind
Creating timing-dependent tests that fail intermittently
Hardcoding test data directly in test functions

faq.question: Which testing frameworks are compatible?
faq.answer: Patterns are framework-agnostic and work with pytest, Jest, Mocha, or any testing framework

faq.question: What coverage percentage should I aim for?
faq.answer: Core logic needs 90%, API routes 80%, utilities 70%. Adjust based on project requirements

faq.question: Can I integrate with existing CI systems?
faq.answer: Yes, patterns include CI integration guidelines for GitHub Actions, Jenkins, or any CI platform

faq.question: Is my test data safe?
faq.answer: Yes, this is documentation-only with no data collection. Test data stays in your environment

faq.question: Tests are still flaky, what should I check?
faq.answer: Review the red flags section - ensure proper isolation, avoid timing dependencies, use fixtures

faq.question: How does this compare to testing tutorials?
faq.answer: This provides production-ready patterns used in enterprise projects, not basic examples
